previous_headings: Bigger changes
title: Contributing to fellingdater
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("ropensci/fellingdater", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

what: fellingdater: Estimate, report and combine felling dates of historical tree-ring series
title: Get started
text: R-package offers suite functions designed assist inferring estimates felling dates dated tree-ring series. presence (partially) preserved sapwood waney edge allows (pre-)historical timber allows estimate missing number sapwood rings. estimate, range actual felling date can determined reported, individual series well group related timbers. cases can assumed group historical timbers felled simultaneously (.e., year), due absence bark/cambial zone (waney edge) final formed tree ring, determined, preserved sapwood rings can used establish date range felling event. Taking account observed number sapwood rings across analysed samples combining single estimate, accurate precise estimation felling date year group timbers study likely obtained. vignette provides quick overview package main functions, including new tool sum sapwood probability distributions, comparable ‘summed probability densities (SPD)’ commonly applied sets radiocarbon (14C) dates.

previous_headings: fellingdater: Estimate, report and combine felling dates of historical tree-ring series > Main functions
title: Get started
text: function calculates probability density function (PDF) highest probability density interval (HDI) range potential felling dates, based observed number sapwood rings, chronological dating selected sapwood data model. example , observe 10 sapwood rings sample (last ring dated 1234 AD) originates Southern Baltic region. sapwood model published Wazny, 1990 covers provenance region. hdi delineates interval actual felling date likely situated. represents shortest interval within probability distribution given probability mass credible interval. HDI summarizes distribution specifying interval spans distribution, typically 95%, every point inside interval higher credibility point outside interval. hdi = FALSE, matrix returned scaled p-values number observed sapwood rings. results procedure can visualized setting plot = TRUE.
code: sw_interval(      n_sapwood = 10,      last = 1234,      hdi = TRUE,      cred_mass = .95,      sw_data = "Wazny_1990",      densfun = "lognormal" ) #>   lower upper         p #> 1  1234  1250 0.9611793 # 10 sapwood rings observed and the Wazny 1990 sapwood model: sw_interval(      n_sapwood = 10,      last = 1234,      hdi = TRUE,      cred_mass = .95,      sw_data = "Wazny_1990",      densfun = "lognormal",      plot = TRUE )

code: tmp <- data.frame(      id = c("aaa", "bbb", "ccc"),      swr = c(10, 11, 12),      waneyedge = c(FALSE, FALSE, TRUE),      end = c(123, 456, 1789) ) fd_report(tmp,      series = "id",      n_sapwood = "swr",      last = "end",      sw_data = "Wazny_1990" ) #>   series last n_sapwood waneyedge lower upper        felling_date sapwood_model #> 1    aaa  123        10     FALSE   123   139 between 123 and 139    Wazny_1990 #> 2    bbb  456        11     FALSE   456   471 between 456 and 471    Wazny_1990 #> 3    ccc 1789        12      TRUE    NA  1789             in 1789    Wazny_1990

text: function read_fh() extension dplR::read.fh() function allows read .fh (format Heidelberg) files ring widths (decadal, half-chrono chrono format) (Brewer Murphy 2011), focused extracting additional information found HEADER fields .fh files. HEADER fields often harbour essential information necessary establishing well informed estimate felling date, measured number sapwood rings, number observed unmeasured rings, presence HW/SW boundary, presence cambial zone, etc. read_fh() function retrieves information HEADER fields lists items attributes ring-width measurements. fh_header()function facilitates easy conversoin data.frame. example , .fh file ring-width measurements timbers medieval ship DOEL1 (Haneca Daly 2014) read read_fh().
code: Doel1 <- system.file("extdata", "DOEL1.fh", package = "fellingdater")  # When header = TRUE, the get_header() function is triggered and HEADER fields  # in the .fh file are returned as a data.frame, instead of the ring-width  # measurements.  Doel1_header <- read_fh(Doel1, verbose = FALSE, header = TRUE)  dplyr::glimpse(Doel1_header)  # Columns: 29 # $ series            <chr> "K1_091", "S38-BB", "GD3-1BB", "GR1mBB", "S13mSB", "S13A-BB" # $ data_type         <chr> "Single", "Single", "Single", "Quadro", "Quadro", "Single" # $ chrono_members    <chr> NA, NA, NA, "K1_001,K1_004x,GR1-3BB", "S1-3SB,K1_076", NA # $ species           <chr> "QUSP", "QUSP", "QUSP", "QUSP", "QUSP", "QUSP" # $ first             <dbl> 1158, 1193, 1222, 1220, 1164, 1232 # $ last              <dbl> 1292, 1306, 1310, 1310, 1322, 1324 # $ length            <dbl> 135, 114, 89, 91, 159, 93 # $ n_sapwood         <dbl> 15, 0, 5, 3, 20, 19 # $ n_sapwood_chr     <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ unmeasured_rings  <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ invalid_rings     <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, 1 # $ status            <chr> "Dated", "Dated", "Dated", "Dated", "Dated", "Dated" # $ waneyedge         <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, "WKE" # $ bark              <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ pith              <chr> "-", "-", "-", "-", "-", "-" # $ pith_offset       <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ pith_offset_delta <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ comments          <chr> "keelplank", "framing timber", "hull plank", ... # $ project           <chr> "Ship timbers DOEL 1", "Ship timbers DOEL 1", ... # $ location          <chr> "Doel_Deurganckdok", "Doel_Deurganckdok", ... # $ town              <chr> NA, NA, NA, "Doel", NA, NA # $ zip               <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ street            <chr> NA, NA, NA, "Deurganckdok", NA, NA # $ sampling_date     <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ measuring_date    <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ personal_id       <chr> "KH", "KH", "KH", "KH", "KH", NA # $ client_id         <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA # $ longitude         <chr> "4.269711", "4.269711", "4.269711", ... # $ latitude          <chr> "51.298236", "51.298236", "51.298236", ...

title: The ´fellingdater´ workflow
text: function cor_table() computes commonly used correlation values dated tree-ring series reference chronologies. function helps check assigned end date series comparing measurements absolutely dated reference chronologies. might also provide information timber provenance, reference chronologies represent geographically confined region. information allows select appropriate sapwood model tree-ring data according provenance wood. correlation values computed : glk: ‘Gleichläufigkeit’ ‘percentage parallel variation’ (Buras Wilmking 2015; Eckstein Bauch 1969; Huber 1943; Visser 2021). glk_p: significance level associated glk-value (Jansma 1995). r_pearson: Pearson’s correlation coefficient. t_St: Student’s t-value based r_pearson. t_BP: t-values according algorithm proposed Baillie Pilcher (1973). t_Ho: t-values according algorithm proposed Hollstein (1980).
code: Doel1_trs <- read_fh(Doel1, header = FALSE) Hollstein_crn <- read_fh("Hollstein80.fh", header = FALSE)  cor_table(x = Doel1_trs,           y = Hollstein_crn,           min_overlap = 80, # sets the minimum overlap between series and reference           output = "table",           sort_by = "t_BP")

what: Tree-ring dating and estimating felling dates of historical timbers
title: Tree-ring dating and estimating felling dates of historical timbers
text: fellingdater package provides suite functions dendrochronological dendroarchaeological analysis, covering workflow tree-ring data processing crossdating, estimation reporting felling dates. Originally designed assist dendrochronologists inferring felling dates dated tree-ring series partially preserved sapwood, package expanded include workflow tree-ring dating, analysis, visualization.

title: Tree-ring dating and estimating felling dates of historical timbers
text: can install latest release fellingdater GitHub R-universe:
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("ropensci/fellingdater") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("ropensci/fellingdater")

previous_headings: Core functionality
title: Tree-ring dating and estimating felling dates of historical timbers
text: Data generation preparation: Create synthetic datasets trs_pseudo_rwl(), read prepare real data read_fh(), trs_select(), trs_remove() trs_trim(). Crossdating analysis: Perform crossdating trs_crossdate() set end dates tree-ring series trs_date_end(). statistical measures crossdating procedure include: t-values according Hollstein (1980) Baillie & Pilcher (1973) transformation procedures (trs_tho()trs_tbp()) percentage parallel variation, including (Semi-)Synchronous Growth Changes (SGC SSGC, Visser 2020), Gleichläufigkeit (Buras & Wilmking 2015, Eckstein & Bauch 1969, Huber 1943) associated significance level (Jansma 1995) (trs_pv()) correlation measures, r Pearson t-values (trs_tSt()) Visualization: Display crossdating results trs_plot_dated(), individual series trs_plot_rwl()

previous_headings: Core functionality
title: Tree-ring dating and estimating felling dates of historical timbers
text: package’s primary focus estimating felling dates accurately dated tree-ring series preserved sapwood (sw). bark/cambial zone (waney edge) absent, preserved sapwood rings can used establish date range felling event, allowing researchers report interval actual felling date (fd) likely falls. procedure can applied individual series well collection related timbers. Individual series: Estimate felling date ranges tree-ring series preserved sapwood. Group analysis: Combine multiple samples assumed felled simultaneously enhanced precision. Probability densities: Work sapwood probability distributions create summed probability densities reflect dynamics felling date intensity.

previous_headings: Core functionality
title: Tree-ring dating and estimating felling dates of historical timbers
text: package workflow progresses logically : Data preparation - Generate synthetic data prepare existing tree-ring measurements Crossdating statistical analysis - Establish accurate calendar dates tree-ring series Quality control - Validate dating results using multiple statistical measures Felling date estimation - Apply sapwood models dated series preserved sapwood Grouping - Combine individual felling date estimates related wooden finds Visualization reporting - Present results publication-ready graphics

what: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: Deprecated: cor_table() deprecated fellingdater version 1.2.0 Please use trs_crossdate() instead. function calculates common correlation values dated tree-ring series (x) set reference chronologies (y). master chronologies provided, series x compared series x. values reported pairs series common overlap >= min_overlap. correlation values computed include: glk: 'Gleichläufigkeit' 'percentage parallel variation' (Buras & Wilmking 2015; Eckstein & Bauch 1969; Huber 1942; Visser 2020) glk_p: significance level associated glk-value (Jansma 1995) r_pearson: Pearson's correlation coefficient t_St: Student's t-value t_BP: t-values according Baillie & Pilcher (1973) algorithm t_Ho: t-values according Hollstein (1980) algorithm

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
code: cor_table(   x,   y = NULL,   min_overlap = 50,   remove_duplicates = TRUE,   output = "table",   sort_by = "t_Ho" )

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: x data.frame class ´rwl' tree-ring data. column represents measurement series, row names correspond (calendar) years. y data.frame class 'rwl' tree-ring data. column represents measurement series chronology, row names correspond (calendar) years. NULL (default), x compared (y = x). min_overlap numeric value specifying minimum overlap required series correlation calculation. remove_duplicates logical value. TRUE, identical pairs series references removed output. output desired output format, either "matrix" "table" (default). sort_by correlation value output sorted series x. One "r_pearson", "t_St", "glk", "glk_p", "t_BP", "t_Ho". Default "t_Ho"

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: function returns list correlation matrices output set "matrix." output set "table," returns data.frame reporting correlation values.

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: function computes various correlation values tree-ring series data.frame x set reference chronologies data.frame y. y provided, compares series x series `x.

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: Baillie, M.G.L., Pilcher, J.R. (1973) simple crossdating program tree-ring research. Tree-Ring Bulletin 33, 7–14. http://hdl.handle.net/10150/260029 Buras, . Wilmking, M. (2015) Correcting calculation Gleichläufigkeit, Dendrochronologia 34, 29-30. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dendro.2015.03.003 Eckstein, D. Bauch, J. (1969) Beitrag zur Rationalisierung eines dendrochronologischen Verfahrens und zur Analyse seiner Aussagesicherheit. Forstwissenschaftliches Centralblatt, 88(1), 230-250. Huber, B. (1943) Über die Sicherheit jahrringchronologischer Datierung. Holz als Roh- und Werkstoff 6, 263-268. https://doi.org/10.1007/BF02603303 Hollstein E. (1980) Mitteleuropäische Eichenchronologie. Trierer dendrochronologische Forschungen zur Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte, Trierer Grabungen und Forschungen 11, Mainz Rhein. Jansma, E. (1995) RemembeRINGs; development application local regional tree-ring chronologies oak purposes archaeological historical research Netherlands, Nederlandse Archeologische Rapporten 19, Rijksdienst voor het Oudheidkundig Bodemonderzoek, Amersfoort. https://dspace.library.uu.nl/handle/1874/45149 Schweingruber, F. H. (1988) Tree rings: basics applications dendrochronology, Kluwer Academic Publishers, Dordrecht, Netherlands, 276 p. Visser, R.M. (2020) similarity tree-ring patterns: Assessing influence semi-synchronous growth changes Gleichläufigkeit big tree-ring data sets, Archaeometry 63, 204-215. https://doi.org/10.1111/arcm.12600

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
code: # example code if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ Doel1 <- system.file("extdata", "DOEL1.fh", package = "fellingdater") Doel1_trs <- read_fh(Doel1, verbose = FALSE) # crossdating ring-width series from Doel 1 against each other:  cor_results <- cor_table(Doel1_trs,      output = "table", min_overlap = 80,      sort_by = "t_Ho", remove_duplicates = TRUE ) head(cor_results, 20) } # }

what: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
text: function reports felling date estimate individual tree-ring series, based presence/absence sapwood /waney edge. three possible modes reporting: terminus post quem earliest possible felling date: heartwood rings observed measured felling date range interval: sapwood rings recorded, bark waney edge present. exact felling date: bark waney edge present measured sample.

title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
code: fd_report(   x,   series = "series",   last = "last",   n_sapwood = "n_sapwood",   waneyedge = "waneyedge",   sw_data = "Hollstein_1980",   cred_mass = 0.954,   densfun = "lognormal" )

title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
text: x Name data.frame least four columms, providing information id's tree-ring series ("series") number sapwood rings observed ("n_sapwood) presence waney edge ("waneyedge") year assigned last measured ring ("last"). Optionally, column specifying sapwood data set (sw_data) can also included. series Name column x id's tree-ring series listed character values. last Name column x lists calendar year assigned last measured ring (numeric vector). n_sapwood Name column x number observed sapwood rings listed (numeric vector). waneyedge Name column x indicating presence (TRUE)/absence (FALSE) waney edge (logical vector). sw_data two options: character string providing name sapwood data set use modelling. one data sets listed sw_data_overview(), name data.frame sapwood data columns n_sapwood count, character string naming column x lists series sapwood model use, e.g. sw_data = "sapwood_model_column". cred_mass numeric scalar [0, 1] specifying mass within credible interval (default = .954). densfun Name density function fit sapwood distribution. one : lognormal (default value), normal, weibull, gamma.

title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
text: data.frame felling date estimates per tree-ring series. Columns include: series: series identifier last: last measured ring n_sapwood: number sapwood rings waneyedge: TRUE/FALSE waney edge lower, upper: numeric bounds estimated felling date felling_date: character summary (e.g., "1500 1510") sapwood_model: sapwood data/model used

title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
code: df <- data.frame(      id = c("trs1", "trs2", "trs3", "trs4"),      swr = c(7, 1, 10, 12),      waneyedge = c(FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, TRUE),      end = c(1482, 1475, 1490, 1498) ) fd_report(df,      series = "id",      n_sapwood = "swr",      last = "end",      sw_data = "Wazny_1990" ) #>   series last n_sapwood waneyedge lower upper          felling_date #> 1   trs1 1482         7     FALSE  1483  1501 between 1483 and 1501 #> 2   trs2 1475         1     FALSE  1482  1500 between 1482 and 1500 #> 3   trs3 1490        10     FALSE  1490  1506 between 1490 and 1506 #> 4   trs4 1498        12      TRUE    NA  1498               in 1498 #>   sapwood_model #> 1    Wazny_1990 #> 2    Wazny_1990 #> 3    Wazny_1990 #> 4    Wazny_1990  # Example with different sw_model for individual series # You can add a user-defined sapwood dataset as well.  sapwood_model_column <- c(      "Sohar_2012_ELL_c",      "Wazny_1990",      "Hollstein_1980",      "vanDaalen_Norway" )  df2 <- cbind(df, sw_data = sapwood_model_column)  fd_report(df2,      series = "id",      n_sapwood = "swr",      last = "end",      sw_data = "sw_data" ) #>   series last n_sapwood waneyedge lower upper          felling_date #> 1   trs1 1482         7     FALSE  1482  1493 between 1482 and 1493 #> 2   trs2 1475         1     FALSE  1482  1500 between 1482 and 1500 #> 3   trs3 1490        10     FALSE  1490  1514 between 1490 and 1514 #> 4   trs4 1498        12      TRUE    NA  1498               in 1498 #>      sapwood_model #> 1 Sohar_2012_ELL_c #> 2       Wazny_1990 #> 3   Hollstein_1980 #> 4 vanDaalen_Norway #' @importFrom rlang .data

what: fellingdater: Tree-ring dating and estimating felling dates of historical timbers — fellingdater
title: fellingdater: Tree-ring dating and estimating felling dates of historical timbers — fellingdater
text: fellingdater provides comprehensive suite functions dendrochronological dendroarchaeological analysis, covering workflow tree-ring data processing crossdating, estimation reporting felling dates. Originally designed assist dendrochronologists inferring felling dates dated tree-ring series partially preserved sapwood, package expanded include workflow tree-ring dating, analysis, visualization.

what: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
text: function returns matrix 'upper' 'lower' limits hdi (highest density interval), associated probability 'p'. function first sorts input data.frame - columns 'n_sapwood´ 'p' (associated probability) - column 'p' decreasing order calculates HDI finding first value sorted probabilities higher specified cred_mass. finds indices values greater equal threshold, uses indices find 'upper' 'lower' limits hdi. function also calculates probability interval. final result returned matrix 'lower', 'upper', 'p' values. function applied functions sw_model sw_interval.

title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
code: hdi(x, a = "n_sapwood", b = "p", cred_mass = 0.954)

title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
text: x data.frame columns n_sapwood p (associated probability). x computed functions sw_model, sw_interval, sw_combine. name column x lists number sapwood rings. b name column x lists associated probability n sapwood rings. cred_mass scalar [0, 1] specifying mass within credible interval (default = .954).

title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
text: matrix ´upper´ ´lower´ limits hdi, associated probability ´p´.

title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
code: tmp <- data.frame(n_sapwood = seq(1,30, 1),                   p = dnorm(seq(1,30, 1), 15, 5)) hdi(tmp, cred_mass = 0.954) #>   lower upper         p #> 1     5    25 0.9645785

what: Compute a running mean on a time series — mov_av
title: Compute a running mean on a time series — mov_av
text: vectorized function computes running mean/moving average continuous (time) series specified window width.

title: Compute a running mean on a time series — mov_av
code: mov_av(x, w = 11, align = "center", edges = "fill")

title: Compute a running mean on a time series — mov_av
text: x numeric vector length(x), time series data. w width moving average window. wis even, one value future included. align alignment window relative current data point. can one : align = "center": average assigned center window (default). align = "left": average includes current value next (w-1) values. align = "right": average includes current value previous (w-1) values. edges Defines values computed start end series. Options : edges = "fill": average calculated decreasing number values near edges vector (default). edges = "nofill": result includes NA values window cover w values.

title: Compute a running mean on a time series — mov_av
text: numeric vector length x computed running mean values.

title: Compute a running mean on a time series — mov_av
code: num_vec <- sample(seq(50, 100, 1), 100, replace = TRUE) filtered <- mov_av(num_vec, w = 5, align = "center", edges = "nofill") plot(num_vec, type = "l") lines(filtered, col = "darkblue")

what: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: function reads Heidelberg format file (.fh) containing ring width data returns HEADER fields attributes data.frame´measurement data. Heidelberg file format described detail : https://www.treeringsociety.org/resources/SOM/Brewer_Murphy_SupplementaryMaterial.pdf

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
code: read_fh(fname, BC_correction = FALSE, verbose = TRUE, header = FALSE)

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: fname character vector specifying name .fh file read. BC_correction logical. TRUE correction moves BC-dates one year forward. verbose logical. FALSE, messages suppressed reading process. header logical. TRUE HEADER fields returned data.frame; FALSE, measurement data returned.

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: header TRUE, data.frame returned HEADER fields attributes. header FALSE, data.frame class rwl ring-width measurements columns returned, (calendar) years row names.`

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: function reads .fh file ring width data either block (decadal format) column format (e.g., comment flags) used TSAP program. function also capable reading chronologies half-chronos decadal format. read_fh function case-insensitive. Information found HEADER fields listed attributes data.frame´measurement data. . header fields harvested .fh file include: "Project", "FirstMeasurementDate", "Location", "Town", "Street", "Client", "Longitude", "Latitude", "DateOfSampling", "FirstMeasurementDate", "SapWoodRings", "Comment", "MissingRingsAfter", "InvalidRingsAfter", "MissingringsBefore", "DeltaMissingringsBefore", "ChronoMemberKeycodes", "PersId"

what: Detect synchronous growth changes between two tree-ring series ( helper for trs_plot_dated() ) — sgc_for_plot
title: Detect synchronous growth changes between two tree-ring series ( helper for trs_plot_dated() ) — sgc_for_plot
text: Identifies years two tree-ring series show synchronous growth changes (SGC) increasing decreasing previous year. Based logic used trs_pv() distinguishing synchronous semi-synchronous growth.

title: Detect synchronous growth changes between two tree-ring series ( helper for trs_plot_dated() ) — sgc_for_plot
code: sgc_for_plot(x, y)

title: Detect synchronous growth changes between two tree-ring series ( helper for trs_plot_dated() ) — sgc_for_plot
text: x data.frame one column ring-width values years row names. y data.frame one column ring-width values years row names.

title: Detect synchronous growth changes between two tree-ring series ( helper for trs_plot_dated() ) — sgc_for_plot
text: data.frame two columns: pv_logi Logical vector indicating synchronous growth changes (TRUE) (FALSE) year Numeric vector years corresponding logical values

title: Detect synchronous growth changes between two tree-ring series ( helper for trs_plot_dated() ) — sgc_for_plot
text: function compares year--year growth direction changes two series using logic trs_pv(): Synchronous Growth Changes (SGC): series change direction (+ -) Semi-synchronous/Asynchronous: One series changes , change opposite directions years synchronous growth changes receive TRUE values. Years missing values either series marked FALSE. first year evaluated (previous year comparison) marked FALSE.

title: Detect synchronous growth changes between two tree-ring series ( helper for trs_plot_dated() ) — sgc_for_plot
code: # Create sample data years <- 1950:1980 x <- data.frame(series1 = runif(length(years), 0.5, 2.0)) rownames(x) <- years y <- data.frame(series2 = runif(length(years), 0.8, 1.8)) rownames(y) <- years  # Detect synchronous growth changes sync_growth <- sgc_for_plot(x, y) head(sync_growth) #>      sgc_logi ssgc_logi year #> 1950     TRUE     FALSE 1950 #> 1951     TRUE     FALSE 1951 #> 1952     TRUE     FALSE 1952 #> 1953     TRUE     FALSE 1953 #> 1954     TRUE     FALSE 1954 #> 1955    FALSE     FALSE 1955

what: Combine multiple sapwood estimates into a single felling date range — sw_combine
title: Combine multiple sapwood estimates into a single felling date range — sw_combine
text: function evaluates whether multiple sapwood estimates can combined single felling date range computes resulting interval possible.

title: Combine multiple sapwood estimates into a single felling date range — sw_combine
code: sw_combine(   x,   series = "series",   last = "last",   n_sapwood = "n_sapwood",   waneyedge = "waneyedge",   sw_data = "Hollstein_1980",   densfun = "lognormal",   cred_mass = 0.954,   hdi = TRUE,   plot = FALSE )

title: Combine multiple sapwood estimates into a single felling date range — sw_combine
text: x data.frame least four columns, providing information ID's tree-ring series, number sapwood rings observed, presence waney edge calendar date assigned last measured ring. column describing sapwood data set used modelling computation hdi can provided well. series Name column x ID's tree-ring series listed character values. last Name column x calendar years assigned last measured ring listed (numeric). n_sapwood Name column x number observed sapwood rings listed (numeric). waneyedge Name column x indicating presence (TRUE)/absence (FALSE) waney edge (logical vector). sw_data name sapwood data set use modelling. one data sets listed sw_data_overview(), name data.frame sapwood data columns n_sapwood count. densfun Name density function fitted sapwood data set. one : lognormal (default value), normal, weibull, gamma. cred_mass scalar [0, 1] specifying mass within credible interval (default = .954). hdi logical parameter. TRUE, lower upper limit highest density interval (credible interval) given combined felling date. FALSE, matrix returned scaled p values calendar years covering combined estimate felling date range. plot logical parameter. TRUE ggplot-plot style graph returned individual combined estimate felling date. FALSE, list numeric output modelling process returned.

title: Combine multiple sapwood estimates into a single felling date range — sw_combine
text: @return Depends plot: TRUE: ggplot-style plot showing individual combined felling date estimates. FALSE: list : - $raw_data: matrix combined individual densities. - $sapwood_data: sapwood data set used. - $sapwood_model: density function used. - $cred_mass: credibility mass interval. - $hdi_combine: HDI combined felling date range. - $individual_series: summary agreement indices. - $A_model: overall model agreement index. - $A_c: critical threshold (default 60%). - $model_summary: text summary result.Depends value plot. rationale agreement index outlined Bronk Ramsey (1995; 2009)

title: Combine multiple sapwood estimates into a single felling date range — sw_combine
text: Bronk Ramsey, C. (1995) Radiocarbon calibration analysis stratigraphy: OxCal program. Radiocarbon 37, 425–430. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0033822200030903 Bronk Ramsey, C. (2009) Bayesian analysis radiocarbon dates. Radiocarbon 51, 337–360. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0033822200033865

title: Combine multiple sapwood estimates into a single felling date range — sw_combine

what: Sliding window crossdating analysis using multiple statistical methods — trs_crossdate
title: Sliding window crossdating analysis using multiple statistical methods — trs_crossdate
text: function performs crossdating analysis using sliding window multiple statistical methods: Parallel Variation (GLK/SGC), Baillie & Pilcher t-values, Hollstein t-values, standard Pearson correlation t-values. tests series different temporal lags find potential date positions.

title: Sliding window crossdating analysis using multiple statistical methods — trs_crossdate
code: trs_crossdate(   x,   y = NULL,   min_overlap = 30,   sliding = TRUE,   top_n = NULL,   rank_by = NULL,   pb = TRUE )

title: Sliding window crossdating analysis using multiple statistical methods — trs_crossdate
text: x data frame test tree-ring series rwl format (years rownames, series columns). columns must numeric. y data frame reference tree-ring series rwl format. NULL, uses x self-comparison. Default NULL. min_overlap Integer. Minimum number overlapping years required series pairs compute statistics. Must >= 3. Default 30. sliding Logical. TRUE, performs sliding window analysis testing multiple temporal lags. FALSE, tests lag 0 (contemporary positioning). Default TRUE. top_n Integer NULL. specified, returns top n matches per test series (optional sorting rank_by). Default NULL. rank_by Character NULL. Statistic rank sorting results per test series. NULL, additional sorting applied beyond default ordering. Options "r_pearson", "t_St", "t_BP", "t_Ho", "sgc", "ssgc", "glk". Default NULL. pb Logical. TRUE (default), displays progress bar computation. Set FALSE suppress progress bar output, useful calling function programmatically non-interactive sessions.

title: Sliding window crossdating analysis using multiple statistical methods — trs_crossdate
text: data frame crossdating results containing following columns: series Name test series x length Length test series first Date first ring particular lag position last Date last ring particular lag position reference Name reference series ref_first Date first ring reference series ref_last Date last ring reference series overlap Number overlapping years series reference r_pearson Pearson correlation coefficient t_St Student's t-statistic t_BP Baillie & Pilcher t-statistic t_Ho Hollstein t-statistic sgc Synchronous Growth Change (SGC) statistic ssgc Semi-SGC statistic sgc_p SGC p-value glk Gleichläufigkeit (GLK) statistic glk_p GLK p-value

title: Sliding window crossdating analysis using multiple statistical methods — trs_crossdate
text: function implements sliding window crossdating, fundamental technique dendrochronology dating wood samples unknown age. process involves: Determining range possible lags based series overlap lag, shifting test series temporally Computing crossdating statistics Returning results tested position sliding window approach allows identification temporal position test reference series show maximum similarity, indicates likely dating test series. Statistical Methods: t_BP: t-values according Baillie & Pilcher (1973) algorithm t_Ho: t-values according Hollstein (1980) algorithm sgc, sgc_p: synchronous growth change associated significance level (Visser 2020) ssgc: semi-synchronous growth change (Visser 2020) glk, glk_p: 'Gleichläufigkeit' 'percentage parallel variation' (Buras & Wilmking 2015; Eckstein & Bauch 1969; Huber 1942), significance level (p-value) associated glk-value (Jansma 1995) r_pearson: Pearson's correlation coefficient t_St: Student's t-value Sorting Filtering: rank_by = NULL: Results returned default ordering (series, reference, first) rank_by specified: Results sorted per test series chosen statistic (high low) top_n specified: top n matches per test series returned (optional sorting)

title: Sliding window crossdating analysis using multiple statistical methods — trs_crossdate
text: Baillie, M.G.L., Pilcher, J.R. (1973) simple crossdating program tree-ring research. Tree-Ring Bulletin 33, 7–14. http://hdl.handle.net/10150/260029 Buras, . Wilmking, M. (2015) Correcting calculation Gleichläufigkeit, Dendrochronologia 34, 29-30. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dendro.2015.03.003 Eckstein, D. Bauch, J. (1969) Beitrag zur Rationalisierung eines dendrochronologischen Verfahrens und zur Analyse seiner Aussagesicherheit. Forstwissenschaftliches Centralblatt, 88(1), 230-250. Huber, B. (1943) Über die Sicherheit jahrringchronologischer Datierung. Holz als Roh- und Werkstoff 6, 263-268. https://doi.org/10.1007/BF02603303 Hollstein E. (1980) Mitteleuropäische Eichenchronologie. Trierer dendrochronologische Forschungen zur Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte, Trierer Grabungen und Forschungen 11, Mainz Rhein. Jansma, E. (1995) RemembeRINGs; development application local regional tree-ring chronologies oak purposes archaeological historical research Netherlands, Nederlandse Archeologische Rapporten 19, Rijksdienst voor het Oudheidkundig Bodemonderzoek, Amersfoort. https://dspace.library.uu.nl/handle/1874/45149 Schweingruber, F. H. (1988) Tree rings: basics applications dendrochronology, Kluwer Academic Publishers, Dordrecht, Netherlands, 276 p. Visser, R.M. (2020) similarity tree-ring patterns: Assessing influence semi-synchronous growth changes Gleichläufigkeit big tree-ring data sets, Archaeometry 63, 204-215. https://doi.org/10.1111/arcm.12600

title: Sliding window crossdating analysis using multiple statistical methods — trs_crossdate
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create sample data rwl_test <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 2, series_length = 80, end_date = 1950) rwl_ref <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 3, series_length = 150, end_date = 2000)  # Full sliding window analysis with default ordering result <- trs_crossdate(rwl_test, rwl_ref, min_overlap = 30)  # Sort by Hollstein t-values result_sorted <- trs_crossdate(rwl_test, rwl_ref, min_overlap = 30, rank_by = "t_Ho")  # Contemporary positioning only contemp <- trs_crossdate(rwl_test, rwl_ref, sliding = FALSE)  # Self-comparison for quality control self_check <- trs_crossdate(rwl_ref, sliding = FALSE)  # Get top 3 matches per series ranked by Hollstein t-values top_matches <- trs_crossdate(rwl_test, rwl_ref, top_n = 3, rank_by = "t_Ho") } # }

what: Create a pseudo-population of tree-ring series — trs_pseudo_rwl
title: Create a pseudo-population of tree-ring series — trs_pseudo_rwl
text: Generates synthetic tree-ring width dataset rwl format, suitable testing crossdating chronology construction methods.

title: Create a pseudo-population of tree-ring series — trs_pseudo_rwl
code: trs_pseudo_rwl(   n_series = 10,   series_length = 100,   end_date = 2024,   related = TRUE,   trend = NULL,   neg_lin_param = -0.1,   neg_exp_param = 0.05,   ar = TRUE,   ar_params = 0.7,   mean_rw = 100,   noise_sd = 8,   common_signal_strength = 0.75,   prefix = "trs_",   seed = NULL )

title: Create a pseudo-population of tree-ring series — trs_pseudo_rwl
text: n_series Integer. Number tree-ring series generate. series_length Numeric numeric vector length 2. single number, series fixed length. vector two values, series lengths randomly sampled minimum maximum values (inclusive). end_date Numeric numeric vector length 2. single number, series end year. vector two values, series end years randomly sampled within range. related Logical. TRUE, series share common growth pattern (.e., internally correlated). FALSE, series generated independently. trend Character. Type trend apply series. Options: "neg_lin" negative linear trend, "neg_exp" negative exponential trend, NULL trend. neg_lin_param Numeric. Slope linear decline (typically -0.1 -1.0). neg_exp_param Numeric. Rate parameter exponential decline (typically 0.01 0.1). ar Logical. TRUE, adds autocorrelation using AR model. Note: related = TRUE, AR applied common base signal; related = FALSE, AR applied series individually. ar_params Numeric vector. Autoregressive coefficients (e.g., c(0.8), c(0.6, 0.2)). mean_rw Numeric. Mean ring width around data centered (default 100). noise_sd Numeric. Standard deviation noise added series (default 8). common_signal_strength Numeric. Strength common signal related = TRUE (0-1). Higher values produce higher inter-series correlations (rbar). Default 0.75 typically produces rbar around 0.5-0.7, realistic tree-ring chronologies. prefix Character. Prefix used naming tree-ring series (default "trs_"). seed Numeric. Random seed reproducible results. NULL, seed set.

title: Create a pseudo-population of tree-ring series — trs_pseudo_rwl
text: data.frame class "rwl", years row names column representing one synthetic tree-ring series.

title: Create a pseudo-population of tree-ring series — trs_pseudo_rwl
code: # Basic usage pseudo_data <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 5, series_length = 50)  # Variable lengths and end dates with reproducible results pseudo_data <- trs_pseudo_rwl(   n_series = 10,   series_length = c(80, 120),   end_date = c(2020, 2024),   seed = 123 )  # Related series with strong common signal (high rbar) pseudo_data <- trs_pseudo_rwl(   n_series = 8,   series_length = 100,   related = TRUE,   common_signal_strength = 0.85, # Should produce rbar ~ 0.7-0.8   trend = "neg_exp",   ar = TRUE,   ar_params = c(0.7, 0.2),   seed = 456 )

title: Compute Baillie & Pilcher-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tbp
text: function computes crossdating t-statistics series two datasets using Baillie & Pilcher (1973) method. Series standardized using 5-year centered moving average log-transformed computing correlations t-values.

title: Compute Baillie & Pilcher-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tbp
code: trs_tbp(x, y = NULL, min_overlap = 50, as_df = FALSE, transform = TRUE)

title: Compute Baillie & Pilcher-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tbp
text: x data frame test tree-ring series rwl format (years rownames, series columns). columns must numeric. y data frame reference tree-ring series rwl format. NULL, uses x self-comparison. Default NULL. min_overlap Integer. Minimum number overlapping years required series pairs compute t-values. Must >= 3. Default 50. as_df Logical. TRUE, returns results long-format data frame. FALSE, returns list matrices. Default FALSE. transform Logical. TRUE, applies Baillie & Pilcher transformation via trs_tbp_transform(). FALSE, assumes input data already transformed. Default TRUE.

title: Compute Baillie & Pilcher-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tbp
text: Depending as_df parameter: as_df = FALSE (default): list containing: t_BP: Matrix t-values test series rows, reference series columns overlap: Matrix overlap counts (number common years) dimensions as_df = TRUE: data frame columns: series: Name test series reference: Name reference series t_BP: Baillie & Pilcher t-value overlap: Number overlapping years

title: Compute Baillie & Pilcher-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tbp
text: Baillie & Pilcher method involves: Alignment series common years Application 5-year centered moving average series Log transformation: \(\log(100 \times \text{value} / \text{moving average})\) Computation Pearson correlation transformed series Calculation t-statistic: \(t = r \sqrt{(n-4-2)} / \sqrt{1-r^2}\) \(n\) number overlapping observations adjusted subtracting 4 account degrees freedom lost moving average. Negative correlations set 0, perfect correlations (|r| = 1) result infinite t-values.

title: Compute Baillie & Pilcher-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tbp
text: Baillie, M.G.L. & Pilcher, J.R. (1973). simple crossdating program tree-ring research. Tree-Ring Bulletin, 33, 7–14.

title: Compute Baillie & Pilcher-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tbp
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create sample data rwl_test <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 3, series_length = 100, end_date = 2020) rwl_ref <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 2, series_length = 80, end_date = 2015)  # Compute t-values (matrix format) result <- trs_tbp(rwl_test, rwl_ref, min_overlap = 30) print(result$t_BP) print(result$overlap)  # Compute t-values (data frame format) result_df <- trs_tbp(rwl_test, rwl_ref, min_overlap = 30, as_df = TRUE) print(result_df)  # Self-comparison within single dataset self_comparison <- trs_tbp(rwl_test, min_overlap = 40) } # }

code: trs_tho(x, y = NULL, min_overlap = 50, as_df = FALSE, transform = TRUE)

title: Compute Hollstein-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tho
text: x data frame test tree-ring series rwl format (years rownames, series columns). columns must numeric. y data frame reference tree-ring series rwl format. NULL, uses x self-comparison. Default NULL. min_overlap Integer. Minimum number overlapping years required series pairs compute t-values. Must >= 3. Default 50. as_df Logical. TRUE, returns results long-format data frame. FALSE, returns list matrices. Default FALSE. transform Logical. TRUE, applies Hollstein transformation (log growth ratios). FALSE, assumes input data already transformed. Default TRUE.

title: Compute Hollstein-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tho
text: Depending as_df parameter: as_df = FALSE (default): list containing: t_Ho: Matrix Hollstein t-values test series rows, reference series columns overlap: Matrix overlap counts (number common years) dimensions as_df = TRUE: data frame columns: series: Name test series reference: Name reference series t_Ho: Hollstein t-value overlap: Number overlapping years

title: Compute Hollstein-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tho
text: Hollstein method involves: Alignment series common years Computation log-transformed growth ratios: \(100 \times \log_{10}(x_t / x_{t-1})\) Calculation Pearson correlation transformed series Computation t-statistic: \(t = r \sqrt{n-3} / \sqrt{1-r^2}\) \(n\) number overlapping observations (original years, growth ratios). degrees freedom adjusted subtracting 3 account growth ratio transformation. Negative correlations set 0, perfect correlations (|r| ≥ 1) result infinite t-values handle floating-point precision issues.

title: Compute Hollstein-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tho
text: Hollstein, E. (1980). Mitteleuropäische Eichenchronologie. Verlag Philipp von Zabern, Mainz.

title: Compute Hollstein-style t-values between all series in two rwl-style data frames — trs_tho
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create sample data rwl_test <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 3, series_length = 100, end_date = 2020) rwl_ref <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 2, series_length = 80, end_date = 2015)  # Compute Hollstein t-values (matrix format) result <- trs_tho(rwl_test, rwl_ref, min_overlap = 30) print(result$t_Ho) print(result$overlap)  # Compute t-values (data frame format) result_df <- trs_tho(rwl_test, rwl_ref, min_overlap = 30, as_df = TRUE) print(result_df)  # Self-comparison within single dataset self_comparison <- trs_tho(rwl_test, min_overlap = 40) } # }

title: Pre-transform tree-ring series using Hollstein method — trs_tho_transform
text: Computes log-transformed growth ratios tree-ring series following Hollstein (1980) method: 100 * log10(value_t / value_(t-1)). transformation emphasizes year--year growth variations.

title: Pre-transform tree-ring series using Hollstein method — trs_tho_transform
code: trs_tho_transform(x)

title: Pre-transform tree-ring series using Hollstein method — trs_tho_transform
text: x rwl-style data frame years rownames series columns. columns must numeric.

title: Pre-transform tree-ring series using Hollstein method — trs_tho_transform
text: matrix log-transformed growth ratios dimensions input. first row (first year) set NA since previous year exists ratio calculation. Row names match input data.

title: Pre-transform tree-ring series using Hollstein method — trs_tho_transform
text: Hollstein transformation computes year--year growth ratios: $$G_t = 100 \times \log_{10}(x_t / x_{t-1})$$ \(x_t\) ring width year \(t\). transformation: Emphasizes relative changes consecutive years Reduces influence long-term trends Makes series suitable crossdating analysis Values result undefined logarithms (zero negative ratios) set NA. first year series always NA since previous year exists ratio calculation.

title: Pre-transform tree-ring series using Hollstein method — trs_tho_transform
text: Hollstein, E. (1980). Mitteleuropäische Eichenchronologie. Verlag Philipp von Zabern, Mainz.

title: Pre-transform tree-ring series using Hollstein method — trs_tho_transform
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create sample rwl data rwl_data <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 3, series_length = 50, end_date = 2020)  # Apply Hollstein transformation transformed <- trs_tho_transform(rwl_data)  # Check dimensions (should be one row fewer) nrow(rwl_data) # Original rows nrow(transformed) # One fewer row  # View first few transformed values head(transformed) } # }

code: rwl <- trs_pseudo_rwl(n_series = 3, series_length = 50, end_date = 1990) z_rwl <- trs_zscore(rwl) apply(z_rwl, 2, mean, na.rm = TRUE) # should be ~0 #>         trs_1         trs_2         trs_3  #> -3.038975e-16  4.366559e-16  2.591330e-16  apply(z_rwl, 2, sd, na.rm = TRUE) # should be ~1 #> trs_1 trs_2 trs_3  #>     1     1     1

title: fellingdater 1.2.0 (2025-06-30)
text: NEW FEATURES new set functions tree-ring dating, analysis, visualization (trs_*) Data generation preparation: trs_pseudo_rwl(): Generate synthetic tree-ring datasets testing method development trs_select(): Select specific series tree-ring data trs_remove(): Remove series tree-ring datasets trs_trim(): Remove leading trailing NA’s tree-ring datasets single series Crossdating analysis: trs_crossdate(): Comprehensive crossdating analysis multiple statistical measures trs_date_end(): Set end dates tree-ring series based crossdating results trs_tho(): Calculate t-values according Hollstein (1980) transformation trs_tbp(): Calculate t-values according Baillie & Pilcher (1973) transformation trs_pv(): Calculate percentage parallel variation including SGC, SSGC, Gleichläufigkeit, significance levels trs_tSt(): Calculate correlation measures (Pearson r t-values) Visualization: trs_plot_dated(): Display crossdating results highlighting parallel variation trs_plot_rwl(): Plot individual tree-ring series customizable colors styling Enhanced workflow integration Tree-ring analysis functions now seamlessly integrate existing felling date estimation (sw_* functions) Complete dendroarchaeological workflow data processing crossdating felling date estimation Support synthetic data generation real dendrochronological datasets NEW DATASET Weitz_2025: New sapwood model Brussels region (Belgium) based Weitz et al. (2025)

title: fellingdater 1.1.0 (2025-06-05)

Extra checks input (e.g. check_input(), check_duplicate_labels() check_sapwood_data_user(). additional functions added ‘helper-functions.R’ integrated fd_report(), sw_combine() sw_sum(). example data sets testing sw_combine() sw_sum() fd_report() renamed trs_example(1 7) sw_example(1 7).
